justification: "In humans, social concerns can be inferred from economic decision-making games such as the Dictator Game (DG)… Higher donations to in-group rather than out-group members reflect stronger concern for in-group (αI)…"
The same Dictator Game paradigm is said to reveal "concern for… out-group interests (αO)" by comparing transfers made to out-group recipients.

"To infer expectations of reciprocity (viz. βT), studies with humans used Trust Games… Greater transfers reflect expectations of reciprocity, and greater back-transfers reflect a willingness to reciprocate."
"Expectations of competition can be inferred from partner choice, with rejecting partners who did not cooperate on earlier occasions as a measure of negative expectations."

"Reputation concerns have been inferred from third-party punishment games, where participants… express through punishment social disapproval of the others’ (non-cooperative) behaviour and/or induce a norm for cooperation."
Side Box 1 notes that "central oxytocin is obtained from cerebrospinal fluid" to correlate endogenous release with behaviour.
The same box states that "peripheral oxytocin can be obtained from blood plasma…" as a measure of circulating oxytocin.
Side Box 1 lists "saliva" as a non-invasive peripheral source from which oxytocin is assayed to index hormonal activity.
Side Box 1 also names "urine" among fluids from which peripheral oxytocin is measured.
